Thanks for reaching out to me with your concerns. I can understand how worried you must be feeling, but let's try to address your health issues one by one.

Based on your description, it seems like you're suffering from chronic bronchitis with pleuritic pain in the left chest that wraps around the left shoulder blade. An X-ray of your chest might show some dense shadows with thickened pleura, indicating edematous thickened inflamed pleura.

The fact that your cough is producing yellow mucus suggests the presence of infection in the air track. While pneumonia is a possibility, the absence of high fever with chills indicates that you might be recovering from bronchitis with pleuritic pain in the left chest laterally and in the back near the left shoulder blades.

Dear, thank you for consulting with me. I understand your concerns about your daughter's snoring. Snoring can be a common issue in children, and often there is no underlying medical condition causing it. However, it's still important to address the issue and try to find ways to help your daughter sleep more comfortably.

The ENT specialist you consulted may have given your daughter antibiotics to rule out any infection that could be contributing to the snoring. However, if the snoring persists and the specialist has confirmed that there are no physical abnormalities, then there are a few things you can try at home to help alleviate the issue.

Firstly, changing your daughter's sleep position may help. If she sleeps on her back, try encouraging her to sleep on her side instead. This can help reduce the amount of blockage in her airway and decrease the snoring.

Secondly, you can help open up your daughter's nasal passages before bed by using a saline nasal spray or a humidifier in her room. This can help reduce any congestion or blockage in her nose that may be contributing to the snoring.

Thirdly, changing your daughter's pillow or rearranging the height of her pillows may also help. If her pillow is too high or too soft, it can cause her head to tilt backwards and block her airway. Try using a firmer pillow or adjusting the height of her pillows to keep her head in a neutral position while she sleeps.

Lastly, making sure your daughter is well-rested and has a regular sleep schedule can also help reduce snoring. Tiredness and irregular sleep patterns can contribute to snoring, so establishing a consistent bedtime routine can help alleviate the issue.

I hope these tips help you and your daughter find a solution to the snoring problem. If you have any further concerns or questions, please don't hesitate to ask.

What has happened is that because your muscles require continuous oxygen during such sudden, strenuous exercise, and your body is unable to supply it, it switches to anaerobic mode of energy production (where oxygen is not needed). This is like taking a detour from the usual path. The problem here is that due to this alternate mode, a lot of lactic acid is produced in the body as a by-product and gets stored in your muscles. This causes pain, as lactic acid is released from your muscles very slowly. Your back muscles have gone into a spasm. Apply some heat, rest from jogging for 2-3 days or until the pain subsides. Then start slowly. Don't worry, you'll get back to your 4 km run slowly, although a bit slower. Best of luck!

Hello Aubrey,

Thank you for reaching out. As a spine surgeon, I can assist you with your first concern regarding the convex curve in your back.

The convex curve you described is known as kyphosis when it is in front of the back plane, while a side-to-side curve is called scoliosis. If your kyphosis is postural, which is common in adolescent girls and presents with stooped shoulders and a slouched trunk, it can be corrected through physical therapy and strengthening of your back muscles with posture training.

However, if the kyphosis is structural, meaning the alignment of your vertebrae is fixed in a kyphotic position, it may require surgical correction. This is typically indicated if there is associated weakness in the legs or difficulty walking and is not purely for cosmetic reasons. To determine whether you have postural or structural kyphosis, an X-ray of your spine would be necessary.

In summary, it is likely that you have postural kyphosis. I recommend consulting with a skilled physical therapist who can guide you through appropriate exercises and therapy to address this issue.

Regarding your second problem of a permanently blocked nose, facial swelling, and small-appearing eyes, I suggest consulting an otolaryngologist (ear, nose, and throat specialist) or an allergist/immunologist who can better address these symptoms as they fall outside my area of expertise. * Install an air conditioner or dehumidifier.

Jaundice is a symptom of the rise of yellowish pigments (bilirubin in your body) which are normally converted by the liver into soluble forms and excreted into the gut to be excreted out of the body in the stools. The first incidence of its rise, which you experienced in your neonatal life and resolved itself, is a type called physiological jaundice and is not considered a disease, so there is no need to worry about that. But the second incidence in your adolescence may be due to acute hepatitis, which in most cases is viral. However, its recurrence is a greater concern as it requires a detailed evaluation to rule out any other cause of chronic liver disease. Although such higher levels of ALT are usually present in Hepatitis A or E, which resolves itself in approximately 1-2 weeks. Your GGT levels indicate around 5 times the normal levels of your age group, which suggests intrahepatic homeostasis or inflammatory hepatitis, again favoring an acute inflammatory cause that is most likely viral and is a water-borne disease with self-remission. If these levels were as high as 10-30 times, we would have suspected any obstruction of bilirubin outflow (aka biliary tract diseases), which are unlikely in your case. Additionally, there are some diseases that interfere with the conversion of insoluble bilirubin into soluble ones or with excretion inside liver cells due to enzyme deficiencies. When present or detected in adolescence or later, it is mostly Gilbert's disease, which only requires monitoring along with symptomatic care and no long-term treatment. If I were your physician, I would order viral sexologies for hepatitis, along with an ultrasound for liver size and structure as well as outflow tracts from the liver and their patency, and albumin-globulin ratios. I would also be interested in knowing the synthetic functions of your liver by monitoring INR to see if there is any need for vitamin K supplementation. Applying cool, wet compresses to the affected area or taking a cool bath can also help to alleviate symptoms. Crying is your baby's way of communicating any or all of those needs and ensuring a response from you. It's sometimes hard to work out what your baby is telling you. But in time you will learn to recognize what your baby needs. And as your baby grows, she'll learn other ways of communicating with you, such as making eye contact, making noises, and smiling, all of which reduce her need to cry for attention. I usually refer to them as 7 reasons for a baby to cry: hunger, a wet diaper, too cold or too hot environment, need to be held close, need rest, need something to make them feel better, and furthermore, need something but they don't know what. Slowly, you will learn to answer these questions for your baby. If a child cries constantly for more than 6 hours for no obvious reasons, then they should be seen by a doctor.

Hello, I have reviewed your case. Based on your symptoms and findings, it appears that you have osteoarthritis in your knee. I recommend starting cartilage-protecting medication, such as Chen Chat Doctor. It would be advisable to get an X-ray of your knee, and if necessary, an MRI can also be done. Physiotherapy treatments like ultrasound and TENS can be helpful, along with knee exercises. Making certain lifestyle changes can also help reduce pain, including:

1. Load Reduction: Protecting the joint from excessive load can slow down cartilage loss and help relieve pain. If you are overweight, reducing your weight can be beneficial. Wearing shock-absorbing shoes, avoiding activities like climbing stairs, and using a walking stick can also be helpful.
2. Activity Modification: It's important to maintain as much activity and joint motion as possible, but high-impact activities can aggravate arthritis. Running and jumping may accelerate cartilage loss in the joint, so it's best to focus on low-impact activities like swimming or cycling.
3. Using Canes: Assistive devices can make it easier to move around without stressing your painful joint. A cane can help take weight off your knee or hip as you walk. Be sure to carry the cane in the hand opposite the leg that hurts.
4. Analgesic Medication: Over-the-counter medications like acetaminophen can often be sufficient for pain relief. If this doesn't control the pain, your doctor may prescribe a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID).

Hi, Thank you for posting your query. Let me address your concerns regarding Boniva. Boniva belongs to a class of medications called bisphosphonates, which work by slowing down or stopping the breakdown of bone. This helps increase bone density and reduces the risk of fractures.

Boniva is taken as a monthly pill or injection. After taking one pill, it stays in your system and continues working for the full month before the next dose. It is important to take it as prescribed by your doctor to ensure effective treatment.

Other options for treating osteoporosis include other bisphosphonates, such as Fosamax and Actonel. These medications work similarly to Boniva but may have different dosing instructions and side effects.

In addition to medication, vitamin D and calcium supplementation are important for maintaining bone health. Regular exercise, such as weight-bearing activities and strength training, can also help improve bone density.

I hope this information helps alleviate some of your concerns about Boniva and osteoporosis treatment. If you have any further questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask. Wishing you good health.

Hello and welcome to Ask A Doctor Service. I have read your question and here is my response. It seems like you are experiencing postural hypotension, which is a drop in blood pressure when standing up from a sitting or lying position. This can cause dizziness and is commonly seen in individuals with diabetes, especially if the diabetes is not well-controlled. Meclizine is a medication often used to treat dizziness, but it can have side effects such as weakness and an increase in blood sugar levels. It's possible that the meclizine is causing your diabetes to become more uncontrolled.

It's important to discuss this with your doctor and have your blood pressure checked while lying, sitting, and standing to determine if you have autonomic dysfunction, which is a complication of diabetes that affects the nervous system's control of involuntary functions such as blood pressure and heart rate. Your doctor can examine you for postural hypotension and adjust your treatment plan accordingly. Additionally, it may be helpful to work with a diabetes educator or nutritionist to develop a comprehensive plan for managing your diabetes, including medication, diet, and exercise.

As for pain management, there are multiple levels of treatment. The first level is addressing the underlying issue, which in this case could be surgery. The second level is managing the pain caused by the problem, which could involve nerve pills or muscle relaxants. Amitriptyline is a medication that works at both the nerve and spine levels to block pain signals.

The third level of treatment involves managing the context in which the pain is experienced. This is where mindfulness, yoga, and physical therapy come in. While there is some debate about the effectiveness of these treatments, they can be helpful in reducing pain perception and increasing one's ability to manage pain. 1510: Blood ammonia primarily comes from the bacterial breakdown of absorbed dietary protein in the intestine. Intestinal ammonia enters the bloodstream and travels to the liver, where it is converted into urea. Urea is then excreted from the body through the urine. High blood ammonia levels can be caused by various chronic liver diseases, acute liver failure, and gastrointestinal bleeding (any condition that increases protein in the gut). Additionally, certain medications like valproic acid and excessive protein intake can also lead to high blood ammonia levels. It is possible that bacteria in the gut could contribute to high blood ammonia levels, and antibiotics like Cipro may be helpful in reducing ammonia levels by altering the gut bacterial population. However, further evaluation and testing are usually necessary to determine the underlying cause of high blood ammonia levels.

Hello Mr Santos, I am sorry to hear about your diagnosis. From what you have described, I understand that you are suffering from "Portal Hypertension", which is a complication of cirrhosis of the liver. This condition can lead to either esophageal varices (which can bleed) or ascites (fluid build-up in the abdomen). Cirrhosis of the liver also prevents certain chemicals in the body from being properly purified, which can enter the brain and cause symptoms such as sleepiness and confusion (encephalopathy). The medications you are currently taking, Propranolol and Lactulose, are designed to help manage these complications. Propranolol helps to decrease the portal hypertension and prevents the varices from bleeding, while Lactulose prevents the absorption of these harmful chemicals in the intestine and thus prevents encephalopathy.

The prognosis for your cirrhosis will depend on the underlying cause. Unfortunately, irreversible damage has already occurred to your liver, and now the focus is on preventing further deterioration and managing complications. If your cirrhosis is due to alcohol use, complete abstinence can help delay progression. However, if it is due to hepatitis, there may not be much more that can be done as anti-hepatitis treatments are not effective in cirrhosis.

At this stage, the best treatment option for you would be a liver transplant. This would not only remove the cirrhotic liver but also completely resolve the portal hypertension. I strongly advise you to actively seek out a liver transplant center and get evaluated for candidacy for a transplant. I hope this information is helpful, and please feel free to contact me directly for any further details at rxsuresh@gmail.com.

Hemodialysis is a procedure in which a machine is used to filter harmful waste, excess salt, and fluid from your blood. Dialysis is recommended for patients with renal failure due to various causes, as well as for those with pulmonary edema that does not respond to diuretics, poisoning, severe bleeding, ASCIIs without hepatic disease, infectious complications, severe hypertension, and severe hyperkalemia.

During the hemodialysis procedure, a needle is inserted into your arm through a special access point. Blood is then directed through the needle to a machine called a dialyzer, which filters your blood a few ounces at a time. The filtered blood is then returned to your body through another needle.

With special training and assistance, it is possible to perform hemodialysis at home. However, long-term dialysis can lead to complications such as anemia due to lack of red blood cells, bone diseases, chest problems, low blood pressure, muscle cramps, nausea and vomiting, fever and chills, inflammation of the membrane surrounding the needle, high potassium levels which can affect your heart rhythm, nerve damage, infection, and heart disease.

It is important to follow your doctor's recommendations and guidelines for dialysis treatment to ensure the best possible outcomes and quality of life.

1761: Welcome to Chat Doctor. I have read your query and as your doctor, I fully understand your concerns about your son's health. There are various grading systems to determine the severity of cirrhosis, and the most commonly used and widely accepted one is the CHILD PUGH scoring system. This scoring system requires measurements of serum bilirubin levels, PT INR, and serum albumin levels, as well as an assessment of ascites and encephalopathy. Each parameter is given a score, and the total score is used to determine the class of cirrhosis. 2093: Dear patient, Thank you for reaching out to me with your concern. I understand that you are experiencing pain in your lower right abdomen, which worries you that it could be appendicitis. However, please know that vomiting is only one of the symptoms of appendicitis, and its absence does not exclude the possibility of the condition. The best course of action to rule out appendicitis is to visit a hospital for a blood test and an ultrasound. Additionally, the pain you are experiencing when breathing could also indicate other conditions such as cholecystitis or gastric disorders like hiatal hernia or HERD. I recommend that you seek medical attention to properly diagnose and treat your symptoms. Wishing you good health. Sincerely, Dr. Ivan Comic

2175: Before I tell you the causes of increased bilirubin in the blood, let me explain what bilirubin is. Bilirubin is a yellow-colored pigment that the liver produces due to the breakdown and recycling of red blood cells, so it is a byproduct of the breakdown of hemoglobin. Increased levels of bilirubin in the blood can be caused by sickle cell anemia, allergic reactions due to blood transfusions, liver diseases such as acute and chronic hepatitis, cirrhosis of the liver, liver damage, obstructions in the gallbladder, hemodialysis, side effects of medications, and pancreatic cancer. To determine the exact cause, consult a gastroenterologist for necessary investigations and treatment. In the meantime, I suggest following a soothing diet and regular exercise to maintain your health. I hope this answers your question. Take care and get well soon.

2177:
Hi, Thanks for reaching out. I'm sorry to hear about your father's illness, especially since you are away from him. Given his age and current condition, it's natural to be concerned about his well-being.

The main factors to consider in your father's case are his serum creatinine and blood urea levels. If these levels have remained stable over the past three weeks, it suggests that his kidney function has not deteriorated further. However, if they are unstable, it indicates that he is at risk of developing renal failure in the coming weeks.

Additionally, it's crucial to monitor his response to pneumonia treatment. Certain medications used to treat pneumonia may have adverse effects on his overall health, particularly given his current kidney function. Therefore, discussing the above two points with his healthcare team is essential to understand his prognosis and recovery from pneumonia, considering his kidney function.

I hope this information helps you make an informed decision about whether to return to Sydney from the far north coast. Please keep in mind that I am a Nephrologist providing general guidance, and it's essential to consult with your father's healthcare team for personalized advice. Best wishes for your father's recovery. Regards, Dr. [Your Name]

2198: Thanks for your question on Chat Doctor. I can understand your concern. Given your history of smoking, we should definitely rule out lung-related diseases (such as bronchitis) as a possible cause for your symptoms. I recommend consulting a pulmonologist and undergoing a clinical examination of your respiratory system as well as a Pulmonary Function Test (PFT). The PFT will not only help diagnose bronchitis, but it will also provide information on the severity of the disease, which is crucial for determining the appropriate treatment. Most likely, you will be prescribed inhaled bronchodilators (such as formoterol or albuterol) and inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) (such as budesonide or fluticasone) to manage your symptoms. Try not to worry, and rest assured that these treatments will help improve your condition. If you have any further questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask. Wishing you good health. Thanks.
